bibl.title: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, March 16, 1941

div1.p: Kellogg discusses his efforts to assuage critics in Cuba. He will send Hench photographs of the preliminary "Cuban versions" of Cornwell's painting.

div1.head: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, March 16, 1941
div1.opener:
GEORGE A. KELLOGG
237 WEST HUDSON AVENUE
ENGLEWOOD, NEW JERSEY
3/16/41 Sunday
My dear Dr. Hench,
div1.p:
I just returned from
a weeks trip and found your letter
of the 6th. and one eachletters from the
following
J. H. Andrus - of Camden 2
Mabel H. Lazear. 1
John J. Moran 1.
Albert E. Truby 1.
John R. Kissinger 2.
Hugh S. Cummings M. D. 1.

And the letter from Federico
Gomez of which a copy is enclosed.
This is the letter that worries me.
Apparently, what they want is
to have an American firm (namely
John Wyeth & Bro.) express the opinion that
Dr. Finlay's work was the important
contribution to the solution of the
Yellow Fever problem.

If I write at all, which will have
to wait a day or two at least-
it will be to give them a true
picture of what we have found
and it will obviously not be what
they are after. What a mess I
would prepare for Wyeth if I were
to write them what they wish to
hear. I haven't read Dominguez'
book as it is in Spanish and
French only, as I understand it.
Dominguez - up until now, anyway,
has been willing to allow only
his daughter to prepare an English
translation which has been so poor
that the publishers would not
accept it. I got this story from
Dr. Morton G. Kahn of Cornwell
whom I haven't seen since I
saw you, incidentally.

If I write any letter - it will
be a cagy one and you will
receive a copy.

GEORGE A. KELLOGG
237 WEST HUDSON AVENUE
ENGLEWOOD, NEW JERSEY

As to the 5 X 7 or 8 X 10 photos
of the “Cuban Version” sketches!
Cornwell refused to allow me to
photograph them as he said they
were prepared just to show
color patterns and would look
like Hell in black and white.
(They looked pretty good, but
this is the artist speaking,
sometimes as incomprehensible
to me do to you.)

However - I a bill for
$50000 yesterday - in payment
for the sketches only - and I'm
now free to do with them as
I please. You'll get the prints
in a week. Also the
autographed print of Osler -
which I promised.

As to the original color sketches
which you have seen - it is
entirely up to you as to whether
you show them in Cuba. I believe
your idea to use the black & white
photographs of them at your
discretion is a better plan. There
is no use stirring up the
animals in Havana. As you
say, it will be bad enough
to meet the situation when the
first painting is completed.
(Please send me your Palm
Beach address as I'll mail the
prints of the sketches to you these
air mail.)

When you arrive in
N. Y. City April 25th the sketches
on the new concept of the
picture should be ready.
Mr. Cornwell and I will be
looking forward to your visit.
3
GEORGE A. KELLOGG
237 WEST HUDSON AVENUE
ENGLEWOOD, NEW JERSEY
Dean Cornwells address is.
222 West 59th St. N. Y. City.
My telephone (office) is
(Rector 2-8360 (American Home
Products Corp.
Jersey City, N. J.
N. Y. Exchange
I am having copies of
Truby's Kissinger's and Moran's
also Mrs Lazear's letters made
for you.

We need your material
a few more days - and will
then send it to Rochester.

I've enjoyed the “Funny Book”
version of “Yellow Fever” The
cartoonist obviously had not
seen any pictures of Finlay or
Lazear. Also your story in
the Rochester paper. These are
being returned. Best wishes
for a good trip.
